“There’s a crack in everything – that’s how the light gets in.” -- Leonard Cohen

Integral theory is an elegant and sophisticated map based on all the major methodological systems available in this time of history.  Yet, as any theory, it has also had its share of criticism.   A theory of everything has to make room for everyone, including dissenting views of its own map.   As such, we will explore some of the ideas that tonight’s guest has explored in his recent book, "Bald Ambition: A Critique of Ken Wilber’s Theory of Everything."  With love and discernment, we will hold a mirror up to the AQAL map that has manifested from Wilber’s philosophical narrative.

Jeff Meyerhoff, M.A., L.S.W. is the author of "Bald Ambition: A Critique of Ken Wilber's Theory of Everything" and other essays on Integral theory, many that have appeared on IntegralWorld.net. He majored in economics and sociology and has studied philosophy, psychology, politics and spirituality. He's been employed as a social worker for the last 18 years. He has a weekly radio show, "The Ruminator," on WMFO that looks at current events, and runs a philosophical blog at www.philosophyautobiography.blogspot.com. Jeff also presented a paper and was a panelist at the Integral Theory Conference in 2010.
item.name: The Integral Critic: An Evening with Jeff Meyerhoff
